member.name: T:Geocortex.Gis.Services.Grids.GridToCoreMapServiceAdapter
member.summary: This is an adapter class that adapts a Grid to a CoreMapService. It allows you to take a grid, and request a portion of it. So, for exmaple, you could request the adapter to draw the top left corner of the grid, or some extent in the center. This is not a fully functional map service and is only for the purposes of adapting a Grid so that it can be drawn by a map at the extent at which the grid was created. It is not fully functional in the sense that it does not suppose extent scaling. So although, you can ask the adapter to draw a portion of the grid, you cannot "zoom in" or "zoom out" on any portion of the grid. By allowing you to request portions or "tiles" of a grid, it allows a map grid to be constructed from a sequence of tiles, which is useful for drawing large maps.

member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum scale as the lower denominator. If for example the minimum scale is 1:60,000 then the value of MinScale here should be just 60,000. Thus, because this number represents just the lower denominator of the minimum scale, the MinScale be greater than the MaxScale.

member.name: P:Geocortex.Gis.Services.IMapService.MaxScale
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum scale as the lower denominator. If for example the maximum scale is 1:20,000 then the value of MaxScale here should be just 20,000. Thus, because this number represents just the lower denominator of the maximum scale, the MaxScale be less than the MinScale.

member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum scale as the lower denominator. If for example the minimum scale is 1:60,000 then the value of MinScale here should be just 60,000. Thus, because this number represents just the lower denominator of the minimum scale, the MinScale be greater than the MaxScale.

member.name: P:Geocortex.Gis.Services.CoreMapService.MaxScale
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum scale as the lower denominator. If for example the maximum scale is 1:20,000 then the value of MaxScale here should be just 20,000. Thus, because this number represents just the lower denominator of the maximum scale, the MaxScale be less than the MinScale.

member.name: T:Geocortex.Gis.Services.Grids.GridToMapFunctionalityAdapter
member.summary: This is an adapter class that adapts a Grid to a MapFunctionality. It allows you to take a grid, and request a portion of it. So, for exmaple, you could request the adapter to draw the top left corner of the grid, or some extent in the center. This is not a fully functional map functionality and is only for the purposes of adapting a Grid so that it can be drawn by a map at the extent at which the grid was created. It is not fully functional in the sense that it does not suppose extent scaling. So although, you can ask the adapter to draw a portion of the grid, you cannot "zoom in" or "zoom out" on any portion of the grid. By allowing you to request portions or "tiles" of a grid, it allows a map grid to be constructed from a sequence of tiles, which is useful for drawing large maps.

member.name: M:Geocortex.Gis.Geometries.Geometry.Project(Geocortex.Gis.Geometries.CoordinateSystem)
member.summary: Projects this geometry from its current coordinate system to the specified target coordinate system.
member.exception: If targetCoordSys is null.
If either the target or source coordinate systems or their projections are not supported.

If the current geometry's coordinate system is undefined. --or-- If the geometry could not be reprojected because it is located in a geographic area that cannot be represented by either the source or the target coordinate systems. --or-- If this geometry in its current state is not a valid geometry. This may be the case if the current geometry is a surface geometry that does not contain at least three segments or a curve geometry that does not contain at least one segment. member.name: T:Geocortex.Gis.Geometries.Wkt.WktGeometryConverter
member.summary:
Converts from well known text to a Geocortex geometry and from a Geocortex geometry to well known text.
Here are some examples of well known text geometry. POINT(6 10) LINESTRING(3 4,10 50,20 25) POLYGON((1 1,5 1,5 5,1 5,1 1),(2 2,2 3,3 3,3 2,2 2)) MULTIPOINT(3.5 5.6, 4.8 10.5) MULTILINESTRING((3 4,10 50,20 25),(-5 -8,-10 -8,-15 -4)) MULTIPOLYGON(((1 1,5 1,5 5,1 5,1 1),(2 2,2 3,3 3,3 2,2 2)),((6 3,9 2,9 4,6 3))) GEOMETRYCOLLECTION(POINT(4 6),LINESTRING(4 6,7 10)) POINT ZM (1 1 5 60) POINT M (1 1 80) POINT EMPTY MULTIPOLYGON EMPTY

member.name: T:Geocortex.Gis.Drawing.Grid
member.summary: A grid is something that you can overlay on the map. It consists of a bunch of horizontal and vertical lines that are labelled and geographically aligned with coordinates on a map. For each horizontal line, the y coordinate is fixed, while the x coordinate varies across the line. For each vertical line, the x coordinate is fixed, while the y coordinate up and down the line. Grids can be produced in any coordinate system. Most commonly the grid will be in a geographic coordinate system, in which case the grid is referred to as graticules. Also common is for the grid to be in the same coordinate system as the map, in which case it is referred to as a measure grid. The purpose of a Grid is to be able to extrapolate the coordinates of any particular point on a printed map by aligning it with the coordinate lines.

member.name: M:Geocortex.Gis.Drawing.Grid.FindNiceDivisionDecimal(System.Double)
member.summary: Finds a "nice" division for an interval, where "nice" basically means whole numbers, or as close to whole numbers as possible. This method should be called only for numbers that are formatted in decimal only. This method will not be produce good results for numbers that are to be formatted in degrees, minutes, seconds.
member.param: The not so nice division, or a starting point to use. The nice division will be close to this, but rounded up or down a bit to make whole (or half).
member.remarks: This method is internal only for the purposes of unit testing.

member.name: M:Geocortex.Gis.Drawing.Grid.FindNiceDivisionDMS(System.Double)
member.summary: Finds a "nice" division for an interval, where "nice" basically means whole numbers, or as close to whole numbers as possible. This method should be called only for numbers that are formatted in degrees, minutes, seconds only. This method will not be produce good results for numbers that are to be formatted as a plain decimal number.
member.param: The not so nice division, or a starting point to use. The nice division will be close to this, but rounded up or down a bit to make whole (or half).
member.remarks: This method is internal only for the purposes of unit testing.

member.summary: Contains information about coordinate a coordinate axis.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: P:Geocortex.Gis.Ogc.CoordinateAxis.Cardinality
member.summary: Gets the cardinal vector.
member.remarks: Gets the cardinal direction which indicates the fundamental direction of the axis. Basically, the point (x1, x2, x3) was to be described in terms of the axes of the coordinate system, the xN would be the position of this axis where n is the cardinality. For a transposed system, the first axis would have the cardinality of 2 identified concretely as being "latitude".

member.summary: Gets the name.

member.name: M:Geocortex.Gis.Ogc.ExtensionHelpers.ShouldTransposeXY(System.Uri,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Determines if the coordinates should be transposed based on the coordinate system and whether or not the service conforms to the order of coordinate system axes. For exmaple, some OWS services such as WMS 1.3.0 and WMTS 1.0.0 have lat/long coordinates in the order of lat, then long. Some older OWS services such as WMS 1.1.0 have lat/long coordinates in the order of long, then lat. ESRI however always has everything in the order of long, then lat, and it really is a more uniform way of dealing with coordinates, since longitude is in the same direction as an x coordinate in typical projected coordinate systems. So to allow for the coordinates to be in a more uniform order, we transpose them. This method determines if coordinates ought to be tranposed.
member.param: Specifies whether the OWS service respects the order of the coordinate system axes.
member.returns: true if the coordinates should be transposed; otherwise false.

member.name: T:Geocortex.Gis.Ows.TileMatrixSetLink
member.summary: A representation of the tile matrix set link concept from WMTS. A tile matrix set link allows for linking something (usually a layer) to a tile matrix set, and for this particular relationship, impose some limitations on the ranges of tiles that are valid for the matrix set. The idea is that a tile matrix set may cover an area that is geographically much larger than the area covered by a layer. The limits define that valid area, so that unnecessary tile requests can be avoided.

member.summary: Gets or sets the unique identifier for the tile matrix set.
member.value: The identifier of the tile matrix set.

member.summary: Gets or sets the tile matrix set.

member.summary: Utility methods for OGC stuff.

member.name: F:Geocortex.Gis.Ows.WebServiceUtilities.OgcDpi
member.summary: The OGC DPI. It works out to a value of 90.7142857142857, but it's calculated as: OgcDpi = MillimetersPerInch / OgcPixelSize, where MillimetersPerInch = 25.4.

member.name: M:Geocortex.Gis.Ows.WebServiceUtilities.ToScaleDenominator(System.Nullable{System.Double},System.Double)
member.summary: Converts from a scale hint to a scale denominator.
member.param: The scale hint. The WMS 1.1.1 specification has this to say about scale hint: "Layers may include a ScaleHint element that suggests minimum and maximum scales for which it is appropriate to display this layer. Because WMS output is destined for output devices of arbitrary size and resolution, the usual definition of scale as the ratio of map size to real-world size is not appropriate here. The following definition of ScaleHint is recommended. Consider a hypothetical map with a given Bounding Box, width and height. The central pixel of that map (or the pixel just to the northwest of center) will have some size, which can be expressed as the ground distance in meters of the southwest to northeast diagonal of that pixel. The two values in ScaleHint are the minimum and maximum recommended values of that diagonal. It is recognized . that this definition is not geodetically precise, but at the same time the hope is that by including it conventions will develop that can be later specified more clearly."

member.name: M:Geocortex.Gis.Ows.WebServiceUtilities.CalculateResolution(System.Double,Geocortex.Gis.Geometries.DistanceUnit)
member.summary: Calculates the resolution (map units per pixel) from a scale denominator.

member.summary: Unions a collection of bounding boxes.
member.returns: A new bounding box representing the union of all the bounding boxes in the collection, or null if the collection is null or empty.

member.name: P:Geocortex.Gis.Ows.WebFeatureService.ConformsToCoordinateSystemAxes
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the feature service will always operate horizontally with respect to any given coordinate system.
member.remarks: As of 2.0.0, WFS implementations are required to honor the order of the axes as defined by the coordinate system. However, prior implementations are required to keep all coordinate systems horizontal (x then y, long then lat, east then north). For ArcGIS, the WFS implementation always honors the CRS's axis ordering.

member.name: M:Geocortex.Gis.Printing.Converter.Layer(System.String,System.String[],System.Double[],System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Composites a series of images (layers) into a single image. An array of files, with the top layer at index 0, and an array of opacities are provided. The method creates a white background and layers each image on to it, starting with the last. A temporary image is created for each composition, onto which subsequent layers are composed.
member.param: The directory in which ImageMagick's executables can be found.
An array of image paths. The images represent layers, with the topmost layer at index zero.
An array of transparencies, from 0 to 100, where 0 is fully opaque. Each index corresponds to an index in the inFiles parameter.
The output path for the final image.
The width of the final image.
The height of the final image.
If false, the input files will be deleted.

member.name: T:Geocortex.Gis.LayerLegend
member.summary: Represents a layer's legend.

remarks.para: A legend tells a map reader the meaning of the symbols used to represent features on the map. Legends consist of examples of the symbols on the map with labels containing explanatory text. When you use a single symbol for the features in a layer, the layer is labeled with the layer's name in the legend. When you use multiple symbols to represent features in a single layer, the field used to classify the features becomes a heading in the legend and each category is labeled with its value.

member.name: M:Geocortex.Gis.Geometries.DistanceUnit.ConvertTo(Geocortex.Gis.Geometries.DistanceUnit,System.Double,Geocortex.Gis.Geometries.Point)
member.summary: Converts the distance from the current unit to the target unit. For example if this DistanceUnit is Kilometers, the targetUnit is Meters, and the distance is 1.5, the result would be 1500.0.
member.param: The target unit to convert the distance to.

The location on the surface of the globe at which to calculate the distance conversion. This is used in the case that the current or target distance unit is linear (e.g. miles, meters, etc.) and the other distance unit is angular (e.g. degrees, radians, etc.).
member.exception: is null. -or- is null.
represents a point at a latitude that is greater than 90 degrees or less than -90 degrees.
's SpatialReference property is null.
member.remarks: There is no need for the to be in a geographic coordinate system; this method will automatically unproject the point to geographic if it is in a projected coordinate system.

member.name: M:Geocortex.Gis.Geometries.DistanceUnit.ConvertTo(Geocortex.Gis.Geometries.DistanceUnit,System.Double)
member.summary: Converts the distance from the current unit to the target unit. For example if this DistanceUnit is Kilometers, the targetUnit is Meters, and the distance is 1.5, the result would be 1500.0.
member.param: The target unit to convert the distance to.
member.exception: If is null.

If attempting to convert to a target unit where the "IsLinear" property of the target DistanceUnit does not match this DistanceUnit. In other words, if attempting to convert from a linear unit to an angular unit or vice versa.

member.name: M:Geocortex.Gis.Geometries.DistanceUnit.ConvertAtLatitude(Geocortex.Gis.Geometries.DistanceUnit,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Converts to the specified target unit, when this unit and the target unit do not have matching "IsLinearUnit" properties (i.e., one is linear and the other is angular).
member.param: The degrees latitude at which to perform the conversion.
member.returns: The horizontal distance at the given degrees latitude.
member.remarks: All conversions (falsely) assume that the earth is a sphere with a radius of ~3,963.1676 miles.
member.exception: If is null.
If is greater than 90 or less than -90.

member.name: M:Geocortex.Gis.CoreMap.GenerateTiledLayers(Geocortex.Gis.MapDrawOptions,Geocortex.Gis.Printing.PrintJob,Geocortex.Gis.Printing.TiledLayerFactory,Geocortex.Gis.Geometries.Envelope)

summary.para: Generates an array of TiledLayer objects, each of which contains a grid of Tile objects. Each Tile object, in turn contains an extent, an output file name and an image descriptor.
This method corrects the desired extent to prevent the final map from being cut off if its aspect ratio is different from the template image's aspect ratio.

member.param: The map draw options for the complete map image.
The overall extent to create a map for.

member.name: T:Geocortex.Gis.CoreMap.TileItemDownloader
member.summary: This class downloads tile images for a TileItem. The TileItem queue is passed in and the class' Run method runs the next item when it is finished its current one. When all items are processed, the Run method returns.

member.name: M:Geocortex.Gis.CoreMap.TileItemDownloader.#ctor(System.Collections.Generic.Queue{Geocortex.Gis.CoreMap.TileItem},Geocortex.Gis.CoreMap.GenerateMapTileDelegate)
member.summary: Construct a TileItemDownloader using the given TileItem queue and delegate for downloading.
member.param: A queue of TileItems to be processed.

member.name: M:Geocortex.Gis.CoreMap.TileItemDownloader.Run
member.summary:
Processes TileItem instances from the queue. It does this until no further items can be found.
If a tile fails to download, the item is sent to the end of the queue and retried when the other items have completed. If the tile runs out of attempts, this method clears the queue so that the Run method on all instances will return as soon as their current tasks are finished.
member.returns: True, if all items in the queue are successfully processed, false if there's an error.

member.name: M:Geocortex.Gis.CoreMap.TileItemDownloader.ClearItems
member.summary: Clears the items queue.

member.name: M:Geocortex.Gis.CoreMap.TileItemDownloader.NextItem
member.summary: Get the next in the queue, or null if the queue is empty.
member.returns: The next in the queue, or null if the queue is empty.

member.name: M:Geocortex.Gis.CoreMap.TileItemDownloader.SendToEnd(Geocortex.Gis.CoreMap.TileItem)
member.summary: Sends a to the end of the queue.

member.summary: Transposes the bounding box if it needs to be transposed. This will have the effect of guaranteeing that the bounding box's coordinates are in a sane order (i.e. long,lat if geographic).

member.name: P:Geocortex.Gis.Services.Ows.WmtsMapFunctionality.RequestEncodings
member.summary: Gets or sets the request encodings. This is really just the preferred encoding, and as such it isn't very valuable to set it to more than one flag value. This value will be validated, and when a tile request is made, it will be made according to a supported encoding from the capabilities. If the preferred capability is not a supported encoding, it will likely not be used.

member.name: T:Geocortex.Gis.Services.TileCover
member.summary: Describes information (and calculates that information) about how tiles may be used to cover a geographic area. Think about if you were to lay some tiles down to cover a geographic area, which tiles would you use, and how would they line up with that geographic area. That is the question that this class is able to answer.

member.summary: Converts to an ArcGIS URL parameter value, in the form: "[StartTime],[EndTime]" where start and end time are both represented as milliseconds since the epoch. If either StartTime or EndTime is null, then they are represented as "null" in the parameter value, which ArcGIS Server will take to mean either the start of time or the end of time, respectively.
